author: vincent_vda
title: Marvel of a set!
review:
This is one excellent set, Lego!

You only need ONE good castle but we seem to get a new one every two years or so. Common buildings and people however come along only so often. I remember the Inn from ages past (and a legend a few years ago) and a blacksmith at the start of the 80's (yes I'm THAT old) but besides from that... not much.

Finally Lego listens to the fans.

The figures are very nice, the buildings challenging and very beautifully crafted. Even the tree is a nice add-on! The market table is very welcome.

More like this, please! A well-deserved top rating.

author: BWhyte
title: Close to a classic but...
review: I just got done putting this together and it was a lot of fun.  There are plenty of minifigs and also tons of cool new pieces like fish and a carrot.  It will be a great addition to my layout and the modular pieces allow you to break it up and place it anywhere in your town.  There are a couple things I would like to see different or maybe changed - 1. I think including one baseplate would be good, a cobblestone street or even a dirt road colored plate. 2. The buildings are not 100% sturdy like others I have built.  The plate for the water and under the stairs is a little shaky.  Other than that a really cool set.

author: zek
title: Simply awsome
review:
I have to say this is one of the best sets I have ever built. It has so many features and wonderfully set out.

Positives:
Great minifig selection including two rare females
Lots of rare and new peices
great design
nice tree addition
lots of detail
water wheel works great
buildings open and close

Negatives:
bird minifigs are lame
needed more gold
tree is a little fragile
stickers

Overall a great set worth the purchace and in time will become one of the classics.

author: uruk
title: LEGO 10193 = EPIC WIN
review: i don't think i can write here anything more, because all you wanna know about this you already know, so i'll just say: if you have an opportunity to buy this piece of lego history, STOP CONSIDERING IT AND BUY IT RIGHT AWAY! this is the best castle set of all times.

author: sudorum
title: This be ye olde grande
review: A great upgrade from the half complete castle sets that come out every once in a while. Great new pieces, a turkey, a cow, new rare minifigs an' more! The blacksmith shop is great with a throttle hammer run by the turning of the water mill. When building the stables, the directions tell you to place two brown "clubs" (like the ones in the Indie sets) in the stables. I'm not really sure what they're supposed to be, but if i were to guess, i'd have to say they might actually be all nat-ur-al "cow pies." The top floor of the stables building has a small furnace and a dining table. There are also pictures on the walls of faces, which are hopefully meant to be drawings since photographs were definitely not invented in the medieval ages. The blue building is probably an inn or a house, and has a detailed inside that includes a bed, fireplace, a dressing room, and a lower floor occupied by a counter with cups and a barrel most likely filled with rum. A must-buy whether you're a castle fan or not, with a decent price considering all the rip off prices of the clone war sets.

author: kcrmccoy
title: Best Lego Set Ever
review:
When I had ordered this set, it said it was on back order. I was disappointed at how long I would have to wait, but I did so anyway. Surprisingly, It gave me a confirmation e-mail a week after I ordered it saying it was on its way.

The Monday I got it, I was thrilled. I opened it up right away. 

CAUTION: WHEN YOU OPEN THIS BOX THERE ARE ABOUT 16 BAGS, DON'T MIX.

It took me about 5 hours to build the whole thing, I'm a slow builder though. When I got done building it, It fit right in with my castle and farm. 

PROS:
-Medieval Buildings
-Water Wheel really makes the hammer go up and down.
-Rare minifigs
-Cool Animals (Chickens, Cows, etc.)
-New Full Turkey piece and other food
-Cool Tree
-You can fold the buildings for easy storage

CONS:
-Leaves fall of easily
-The Blacksmith's shop has one side where it is two studs smaller. Kind of annoying.

Perfect addition to any castle theme. An absolute must if you like Castle Legos.

author: Gus_263
title: A New Classic!
review:
Introduction 

This Castle set is very different in comparison with some current sets (as a main difference, I can say that this is not a castle, but a village, which can expand the subject of Castle and aggregate it to other themes, like Town). It is possibly one of the best sets of the theme, and includes a great number of parts and mini figures, which will be discussed during the review. It was a much awaited launch in 2009, and really is a pity that it's distribution is limited to countries with Shop at Home. I got my exemplar of this set from UK, and I received it in March. Unfortunately this set will not be available in my country. I separated the review in four main parts, to be easier to read. They are Pieces, Construction, Design and Playability. 

Pieces 

The pieces are very important factors to the set's final rate. There are 1601 pieces in total, a very good range, allowing to build castles, houses, and so on. The price for it isn’t very cheap, but worth, it can even be considered "few" for the contents the set includes. The price per piece is very tempting to buy the set. It also has some very interesting colors such as Dark Brown, Pearl Gold, Medium Blue, and others like Tan and Dark Red, more common with the modular houses or exclusives sets. 

As a Castle set, it is important to always have accessories for the knights and to the inhabitants of the village. For the knights, there are a regular number of weapons: three spears, an axe, a lance, and two helmets, one for each knight. 

Other accessories that come in good quantity in the set are baskets, barrels, cups / chalices and the new pieces of fire, (which are curved flames). Other examples of interesting objects are: a brush, a plate, a carrot and two knives. This set also has cool parts such as apples, fish, a chest (with coins), a rat, and turkey (which is rare to see complete, as in this set). There is also a great quantity of parts of plants (14 of them!) to make the tree. But I think they could also be used as vegetation in another way, besides the tree that will be reviewed later. 

There will be used many common pieces for the structures of the houses, like bricks, plates, round bricks and round plates. As mentioned before it have interesting colors, but the most useful with this set are gray and dark gray (technically speaking, Light Bluish Gray and Dark Bluish Gray), included in many different types of pieces. There have a good quantity of bricks, some like the part listed as 30137 in Bricklink and it's derivatives, that are modified bricks which influence the design very well. The brown pieces (Reddish Brown) are included in large numbers. I believe that if those parts are applied to normal and lower houses, they may acquire a Western Sets' style. 

For the roof, many black slope pieces are used. And to keep them, there are many arches. As an essential part as well, there are many columns. There is the presence of a ladder and a door, and more than one type of windows, which is a nice addition. The set includes even "vehicle mudguards”, that are plates / bricks with small arches commonly used in today’s cars and truck sets. Though included in a small number, they’re very useful and have interesting and great uses for the design (although they were already used with some modular houses, so don’t being that new in building of houses). 

The water wheel has a new piece (64566), which I believe can have many uses. Other news are the cows. They have a brown a little different than the bricks that are placed in their back, but nothing that affects a lot. The pieces of horn are very interesting. The only thing that comes to interfere a bit is the fact that they are smaller than the horse (also included in this set). 

But beyond these common and rare pieces, there is what to say about the mini figures. Two knights, a blacksmith, a merchant, two women and two young (one of them have smaller legs, just like as in mini figures of dwarves). Three have the same body, and the knight have the costumes / armor of the knights from the Fantasy Era (sometimes known as Crown Knights). But all have distinct characteristics, from hair to faces (eg, the same hair of Agent Trace is included in this set). And all represent well the medieval theme. Details on each of the minifigs are well balanced, which makes them useful for other themes as well, like in the City theme. One point I don’t like is the head with two faces. Such kind of head has become used many times and more commonly in various themes. Are indeed interesting, but it removes the possibility of use of other accessories than long hair and helmets. It isn’t good to put any hat in mini figures with it, or you may find a mouth "screaming" behind the head of it. 

So, this set is a great source of parts. Rare and common parts, new parts, mini figures in a good number (it is a regular number if compared with some previous sets), useful accessories, and everything that will provide an excellent construction and excellent design. What could be better was the organization of the pieces, they don’t come in numbered bags, and the parts of minifigs comes mixed, which means that almost all bags must be opened, making you spend a large part of the time looking for parts instead of building. Therefore, I suggest building with your family. But it takes time, even more than a set with the same number of pieces. But I do not blame the pieces for this, they are all interesting, useful and well detailed.

Construction 

Following the construction by the book of instructions, the first things to be built are the mini figures and parts from outside the house. Just like the market, the table on the outside and the tree, they are all very easy to build. I believe that there is no right way to put the flowers in the tree, because the instructions do not detail all the positions. So it’s the choice of who owns the set. The tree looks great, but the result of the building isn’t as positive. This isn’t due the design, but I think it is very fragile. It is normal that those plants seem small (or too "flat" to form a tree), but I think the biggest problem is the weakness of the plant and the trunk of the tree.

I think it is cool the presence of a stand of arms, though small (perhaps as small as an impulse set?), it adds more content to the set. Something really cool are three animals that can be done in a simple and fast building, with few pieces (would it be a chicken, a duck and a rooster?). This is great because it reminds a bit of set 375, where the horses were made entirely of pieces. 

Both houses are made from 2 plates (or combination of plates) for each side / part of them. The first to be built (a tan house, it isn’t that yellow as the description of S@H describes it), have a blacksmith’s shop in it’s ground floor. On the outside there is a water wheel, which have a building that was very well thought. As it moves, with a piece of propeller, a hammer can be moved well to a sword (as if shaping it after being forged in the furnace side). 

Meanwhile, on the other side of the bottom, there is not much content as this would be a stable for horses. So far, the construction of the ground floor is in most parts of arches, for internal playability. The connection between the two parts are connected by connector bricks, and above, by connector plates. In the other floor, the construction involves the most common parts, the windows and a fireplace connected directly outside the building for a chimney.  And finally, after some details (such as mudguards), begins the construction of the roof, supported by internal arches. It may seem very simple the construction of this part, but you must note the smallest details for the use of correct parts. It would be somewhat easier if the parts were adequately separated in numbered bags. After that, just add the rest of the chimney and the building of that house is finished. Then, just have to include the final details (flares, a table and a chair inside the house).

The house which predominant color is medium blue have the building’s first steps very similar. But the bottom of the house is more closed, and has a door and some windows (two are fragile, as they are connected by only 2 studs). From above also has a fireplace connected to the main building, and as differences with comparison with the another house, this has different positions of the main windows, and there is only one kind of window on this floor. Instead of a space for a water wheel, there is a space for a staircase. There is no door to this floor, something that could be really good. But anyways, the stair railing and the top of the stairs next to the entrance are very good at design. The roof again requires much attention. In this case, the arches didn’t connect themselves, but support the roof. It sometimes dismantles while it is being built, due a lack of firmness on the roof. Part of the roof becomes stronger after the plates are placed above. As in another house, it has a chimney, but when the house is open, it is in the middle of the structure. The interior is also very detailed, has a small table, a cupboard, a chair (which has no stud, and isn’t fixed on the floor) and a bed (though interesting, it has no studs, losing a bit of compatibility with the minifigs). On the ground floor there are details inside, like the barrels. This ground look like very well a tavern.

The building has some repetitions that are not true problems. The factor of open / close the houses are simple in construction, with only two connections in each home. The building certain times did not appear very strong (like the roof of the blue house) but is quite fun. I recommend that the building is done with family, due the problem of separation of parts, or else the building will continue for a long time to find the necessary parts.

The Design 

the design of the houses (and of the objects and contents as well) is pretty cool. It's all in the European style of medieval times (I just don’t know about the pearl gold color... those houses might be from people of nobility.) So, I guess that it combine well with the old Castle sets (and even some new) and with a layout of Town (maybe like in an old town). The only "problems" in the design would be some objects out of scale, such as the size of the turkey (which is almost the size of the children mini figure) and of the cows, which are smaller than the horse. But anyway, I guess that is common to many LEGO sets (for example, search for images of books for mini figures and see what I'm talking about), but in some ways it’s good, because being bigger, the details will become clearer.

Playability 

The Playability is fantastic! Has much to do in each of the houses! I think the playability couldn’t be better (with 8 minifigs, there is much to do!), and the set after it is built is strong enough (with the exception of the lower windows of the medium blue house and of the tree). It’s fun to play inside the house and even outside (eg. the detail of the water wheel). The tree is fragile, depending on how you hold part of it may fall. But nothing too bad, it is also good for the set. The houses are very resistant both as closed or opened.

Conclusion 

It’s a fantastic set. The playability, construction, parts and design are great. Though it have few cons (like the fragility of the tree and the separation of pieces, which is a major con), it is certainly one of the best sets of the Castle theme ever made. In my opinion is the best of today’s castle sets. Even without the same modular system of the other Modular Houses, this set is one that will be very good to be near a medieval city or layout. 5/5 is the rate I give to this set. Highly recommended for fans of LEGO Castle but also for fans of any themes of LEGO!
Here are some links:

http://lugbrasil.com/forum/index.php?topic=1517.0 – For a complete review with pictures I made (it is written in Portuguese).

http://www.brickshelf.com/cgi-bin/gallery.cgi?f=364806&n=0 – A Brickshelf Gallery with some pictures I took from the set.

Hope you enjoyed the review!

author: that_keith
title: A Long-needed Component of Castle Life!
review:
Finally, the Kings and Knights have some peasants to oversee!

A lot of veteran LEGO Castle fans have always noticed that the Castle world is curiously devoid of common folk.  LEGO Town is jam-packed with a variety of ordinary citizens.. but who are all the serfs that the various Kings and Dragon Masters and whatnot have been "lording over"?

Admittedly, sets like the old Guarded Inn and the hard-to-find Blacksmith Shop have given us tiny bits of Serf City before....  But these now are just supplements to the heart of any village, the Market!

First, I must mention how wonderful the minifigures are!  The old peasant man is reminiscent of the stick-carrying iconic peasant from the cover of Led Zeppelin IV.  And he looks worn out and haggard, a feature which I hope I do not have to explain the rarity of in LEGO-World.  Also, another rarity, TWO female figures with printed dresses... both suitable for a wide variety of roles, although I imagine they will end up being tavern wenches in most scenarios.  Yes, the inevitable random king's soldiers are here, but hey, more catapult fodder.  Finally, more "child" legs!!  The male peasants are quite charming also and do not look like the few peasant figs that have come before them, which is a relief.

The variety of pieces you get is stunning.  Many are small, 1x1 bricks and such, but these come in some interesting uncommon blues and reds and tans.  IT HAS COWS, that alone is worth a paragraph but the wonder of LEGO bovines has been discussed elsewhere.  What was just as interesting to me were the little fish pieces and the whole turkey... very very neat, not to mention the carrot and apple bits.  True, some stickers are in here, but they are at least not covering multiple pieces a la the Wild West.

The design is great, it really looks like some kind of little Germanic peasant town, with a load of gorgeous architectural details.  Also great because it matches a few prior sets (especially the Blacksmith Shop!) quite well.  Interior details are pleasingly elaborate, with checkered "bedspread", little cabinet fronts, a fireplace / oven with a door, and the water-wheel driven hammer setup.

The only flaw I encountered is with the apple tree.  Many brick-built LEGO trees add on flat bricks to more firmly attach the "triangular branch" green leafy pieces... this is not one of those trees.  It looks great, but at the slightest, SLIGHTEST touch, the leafy sections pop right off.  Definitely not great for those who actually play with their LEGOs.  The rest is fairly sturdy, which does seem a puzzling lapse in design.  The water wheel is also often not very smooth in operation (but I may be forgetting which way it is supposed to turn for fast hammering), but this is just a quibble.

Frankly, if every set was so well-designed I'd be pronouncing this the "New Classic Era", but then I bought Troll's Mountain Fortress and this delusion evaporated.  But at least Medieval Market Town is TRULY a stellar set, and one that Castle afficionados will likely list as one of their favorites.  Buy it before it's $400 on eBay, seriously.

And, to any LEGO execs or designers who might see these reviews -- THIS is the blueprint for true LEGO excellence, both from a conceptual (filling-in-the-universe-holes) viewpoint and from a sheer design and value standpoint.  Take note, O Danish Wizards!

author: jonbuddy
title: The Most Detailed and Wonderful Set of 2009!
review:
I finished building this set a day or 2 ago, and I ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT!! It's detail and design bring out the set's uniqueness. The cows have finally arrived in the Lego Universe and amount of minifigs and animals included in this set have brought the score up to a 5!

Pros:
Cows!
8 minifigs (2 Knights, Adult Male Peasant, Old Male Peasant, Young Male Peasant/Squire, 2 Ladies w/ dresses)
Roosters, Ducks, and Chickens, oh my! :P
A WHOLE Turkey
Fish (and plenty of it!)
Market Stand
Nice Stickers
Treasure Chest (w/ coins)
Water Wheel controls Blacksmith Hammer
New fire
Tree

Cons:
The roof pieces on the blue building are tricky to keep in place.

Overall:
It's like being at a Lego Renaissance Fair!

5/5
OR
10/10

Get it while you can! This set is way worth over $100!

author: Lint
title: Best Castle Set to Date
review:
And I say this even though there are no skeletons or trolls!

PROS
-Great value for money (at sale prices anyway)
-Lots and lots of pieces and interesting ones too.
-Beautiful design, lots of colour, houses split open like a doll-house
-Very well designed fun to build AND play with
-A whole turkey, fish, legs of meat, apples, carrot and more!
-Unique villager minifigs! Including females!
-Cute hen, duck and rooster constructions, its great to have imaginative brick designs again.
-Two never before seen Oxen
-A frog!
-Knives!
-Clever house furnishings! Bed, 
-The blacksmiths waterwheel gimmick
-Lots of civilian accessories (hair brush, eating dish, goblets)
-Would make a great centrepiece to all the other human castle sets you own.

CONS
It came with two castle knights and they are nothing new. Would have preferred something more interesting
I feel it should have come with a town squarish baseplate, if not for impressiveness, at least to give the fragile big tree a base to stand on.

Overall I absolutely love this set. Its got a great number of pieces and is very impressive once built. A must have for Castle collectors and highly recommended for anyone in general.

author: lotographia
title: As perfect a set as you'll ever find.
review:
If this website had a 'favourite sets' function, this would definitely be one of them. It's only one set, but it's an entire town. Two or four buildings depending on how you want to arrange them, lots of interesting minifigs, animals, market stalls, a tree, a horse cart, gold, weapons, accessories... this set has the lot. Even after I'd finished building it took me ten minutes to arrange everything to my liking. I'm tempted to buy another set, just to make my village look truly amazing.

Even a perfect set has flaws, though. The same 'peasant' torso is used three times, and the same knight torso twice. Both of the knights have the same helmet, even though there are two other Castle helmets that could be used. Both the women have the same face and two of the civilians have the same cowl.

But these flaws aren't worth marking the set down for, though, especially considering the amount of rare or unique minifigs included.

Highly, highly recommended.

author: Zelyonii_Zaktan
title: Interesting set.
review:
Yes, it's very difficult to buy this set for a man from Siberia (you won't see this set even in Moscow). But I did it.
The price for me was near $200, but for 10193 it's really honest prise.

Pros:
Figs
Cows (i like them very much)
Ineresting houses with very nice interior 
Fun build
1601 pieces

Cons:
 - Bad-printed stickers and patterns. Cows had bad-printed noses.

author: aaronptrck
title: Great Set!
review:
I usually build contemporary sets, but when I saw this set I had to have it!

This set was a lot of fun to build! I always separate the pieces by size and there were sure a LOT of pieces which made for GREAT detail for the set!

Pro:
Accessories! LOTS of little knick-nacks came with this set!
Colorful building
Turbine
Market counter
Barrels of items for sale

Negatives:
Ducks (So that's what they were....)

The reason I gave the set a 4/5 was because of the problem I experienced while building the blue building. Around 3/4 of the way through while building the roof, the pieces collapsed and I had to spend the next 10 minutes fixing the set (UGH!)

Overall it's a great set!

author: abbeylee34
title: Great Set
review:
i love how detailed the building are and how this set can transfer from theme to theme. i rotate themes every three months on my liviing room table. i used it for city, castle, train, and now for a holiday set up which includes the holiday train and toy shop.

pros: building detail, theme transferability, many minifigs, the set is complete-not missing anything

cons: the tree is flimsy

one of the best for the year

author: shgg
title: Flawed gem
review:
This is a beautifully looking set, one that was missing in Castle theme for a long time.
Unfortunately the set suffers from poor quality control - some of the bricks (made in China?) are just cheap, especially those of "pearl" color.
There are some design flaws, as well - insufficient number of hinges makes the buildings flimsy and prone to accidental damage.
Don't get me wrong - I love the minifigs, cows, tons of useful parts and accessories and the overall look of the set, but I am definitely disappointed by lack of quality control in modern Lego sets. They are just not the toys we were used to anymore.

author: M_Tron_Hero_Kodiak
title: Excellent Set - Good to have some Non-Combat related sets
review:
Good set.

I had to wait a year to be able to purchase this set to add my castle collection.

 

The set ranks high in my opinion on all parts.

It did take me a while to build, but that makes it all the more worth while. 

The building construction was excellent, very stable.

 

The only thing bad thing I could see is how many items are not attached to the buildings or a baseplate.    This can be seen as a pro since the items can be moved as however you wish, but in light of most lego sets, keeping things all attached is nice.

 

Excellent set.

author: Town
title: Good set, but overpriced...
review:
Haven't bought a Castle or medieval set in a long time, as I have been focusing on town/city/world instead. I think this could fit in with a modern setting like the other themes, just in a more "historical" district.

Box/Instructions

Nice, as always. High-def pictures all around nice and 'shopped. The black pieces are hard to discern from the dark grey pieces in the instructions as usual.

Parts

Great. Lots of diverse pieces and accessories (including Lego poo! At least I think that's what piece 4521781 is supposed to be). Not sure I like faces on both sides of my minifigs heads since it's not usable when the hair piece isn't on.

Minifigures

Pretty nice selection of characters. Not sure about Lego children still (with the short legs), but they're probably not going away any time soon. Also don't like the blonde wig included as it looks awful. It's way too big.

The build

Interesting accessories, as stated before. And I like the attempt at furniture. Some of it turned out really great. Why can't the city sets and creator houses have the same push? Anyway, some of the build was tedious and repetitive, but I guess to get detail and size that is a sacrifice we have to make. Some occasions with the build also resulted in incredibly flimsy set-ups causing walls and other things to collapse underneath from the pressure of having pieces added on top of them. More or less solved itself when connector pieces joined the sections together, but the end result is that the finished model is slightly "bendy". This is a newer complaint I have with sets when slightly too many detailed pieces are used when larger pieces would have been more efficient; yes I like detail, but not at the cost of stability when building or in areas that the user is not going to see very often.

The completed model

Pretty good, if not a little shallow in terms of the width of the houses. They are sold to us on the front of the package as four roofed section houses, but closing them to make two houses just doesn't look as good. The opened four roof section just doesn't go back very far. I also worry about the amount of small accessories, not attached to any pieces getting potentially lost. Ex: placing small yellow wedge pieces (cheese) on a smooth surface.

Summary

Overall I'm happy with it. It's got a lot of playability, and some interesting characters running around. The furniture and detail pieces are pretty impressive. That said though, I'm not a fan of highly specialized pieces found in this set- Why make a cat, frog, or rat, but then have the user create there own duck/rooster (there are several in this set)? I guess I'm just old school and all of the shiny fish, apples, carrots, whole turkey will take some getting used to. The modernization of Lego means that where we used to use red and green cylinders for apples we now have highly detailed apples (including leaves on the stems). Glad to see that sticker decals were only used for paintings inside the buildings and for flags on the outside, and not for exterior building details like some other Castle sets. Still don't think it's priced right at $99.99. Just doesn't feel like there's enough there to justify that price. I really would love to see a spreadsheet of all the models Lego produces with a per piece price listed. Interesting to see how this one holds up. Will have to do the math later...

Still recommend.

author: Zapp_Brannigan
title: Instant classic, NO QUESTIONS ASKED
review:
I received this set as a Christmas present, and it is the largest set I have ever received. I thought it would be nice to buy a set from another theme other than City for a change, and sure enough, I couldn't keep my eyes off this one. I got it at The Lego Store, which saved me the effort of ordering online.

This is without a doubt the most brutal build I have ever experienced. It was very unwise of me to pour all 1601 pieces into a single large pile. Finding a piece that did not come in bulk (i.e. there was only one piece of that kind and colour) took me at least 45 minutes; building the minifigures and minor parts of the set took me a solid 2 hours simply because I had such a difficult time finding pieces. However, as I went along, the build became easier and less strenuous as more pieces were being used and less remained in the pile. I gave the building experience a four because I did enjoy building every piece of this set, even though the searching was back-breaking. Lesson learned: next time I will sort the pieces into different piles to save myself trouble and time.

The first part you build is the minifigures. Two knights, a blacksmith, a beggar, a peasant, a child, and two maids are included. You are also given a whole heap of animals including two cows, a horse, a frog, a mouse, three types of birds, and five fish. The horse comes with a carriage carrying what seems to be two bales of hay. Accessories include a knife, 5 goblets (3 gold, 1 clear, 1 grey), four apples, a carrot, flowers, a WHOLE chicken with two drumsticks, a battle ax, three spears, a sword, a flag, a treasure chest, three large baskets, four coins, a piece of silver ore, a hairbrush, keg, and perfume. There is also a beautifully detailed tree with flowers lining the outer edge of it, a market stand with price listings, and a large table where the food is placed on.

The next build is the blacksmith shop/stables. The first floor houses the blacksmith shop itself. Here, there is a furnace, anvil with sword, and a hammer used to beat and shape the sword. The hammer moves up and down via the water wheel located outside the building. There are also two stalls for housing the horse. Outside the stalls, there is a small bucket where the carrot is placed for the horse to feed on. The second floor has a fireplace, two portraits, a stool, and a table with a goblet on it. The table top can be lifted off to reveal a gold coin placed inside the barrel on which the table top is placed on.

The final build is the inn. The first floor is a pub. There is a table with goblets on it, a keg, and a barrel. The second floor has a fireplace, a bed, drawer, stool, table, perfume, and hairbrush. The second floor is accessed via a flight of stairs.

Both buildings are hinged such that you can open/close them to allow access to the interior. I enjoy how much attention designers paid to the detail that was put in to the buildings; they truly look like buildings from the Middle Ages. However, what I most enjoy is how this set can be integrated nicely into the city theme even though it is a castle set. This set can be the historical district, heritage park, or tourist attraction of your city.

There are some minor problems I would like to address. For example, the inn's second floor entrance does not have a door. The second issue is that everything is very cluttered without a baseplate. I used a grey 16x32 baseplate to place all the things on, and it looks much better. However, these problems are very insignificant.

Overall, this set is phenomenon and I know it will become a classic for years to come. For $149.99 CAD you can't get a deal better than this considering all the pieces you get (9.4 cents/piece). I recommend this set to any Lego fan, because YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT AT ALL.

author: cllmkrr
title: Why isn’t this a Pirates set?!?!
review:
In my life I have seen a lot of Castle sets fly by over the years and to be honest I’ve never been very interested in any of them before but the day I first laid my eyes upon this I knew I had to have it. Then about a year later I finally had it in my possession and I was really surprised about how difficult it was to build since I was expecting it to have numbered bags like other sets the same size for example the Brickbeard’s Bounty and the skeleton tower (which was another Castle set which attracted my attention). It did take a very long time to build but it was a great experience and when it was finished it completely blew me away, not because of its exquisite detail but from its size.

It doesn’t have much playability apart from the only functions being the spinning waterwheel which drives the hammer in the Blacksmith shop and how you can open the two buildings up and see the individual rooms inside which the Minifigures fit perfectly with lots of headroom to spare. The two buildings don’t seem right for the time period since one looks like it’s from the Tudor era and the other from the Georgian era but besides this they are brilliantly detailed and both consist of...

·         A Blacksmith shop which has a fire pit and a hammer which strikes a sword on an anvil which is caused by spinning the water wheel on the exterior with a rack of freshly made weapons consisting of two pikes and an axe

·         The Stables has two opening gates, a light grey rat and a bucket with an carrot inside it

·         Above the Stables and the Blacksmith lies is either a flat or a Bakery which has two pictures of a male and a female Minifigure, an oven with an opening door and a table and chair which has a grey goblet on it and a secret compartment where you can hide some money  

·         A Tavern with a bar with three gold goblets and a barrel of ale, the upstairs bedroom has a yellow hairbrush, a perfume bottle, a dressing up table complete with stool, a bed that a Minifigure can lie on, a small fireplace and all this is accessible by an exterior staircase

·         And a kitchen or bakery above the stables and Blacksmith shop

This set comes with a lot of accessories with this set which really make it special and unlike any other. The main one would have to be the tree which is really well done and would be a perfect addition to any collection, a market stall with a tub of fish (Five) green apples (Four) and red and pink flowers, to accompany these comes a pricelist telling how much either the fish, apples or flowers cost. There is a table that comes with a spectacular feast of cheese, strawberries, turkey and a gold dish of crackers. There is a chest of gold coins and horse drawn kart that carries two light tan two by three bricks which represent two hay bales.  The animals that come with the set are really special, they consist of...

·         Two brown cows which are exclusive to this set.

·         A white horse

·         A brick built Chicken, Cockerel and Duck

·         A  green Frog

The Minifigures in this set are some of the best I’ve ever seen and they are...

·         A Tavern maid who is exclusive to the set with a double sided head (Happy & scared) and a printed slanted brick instead of legs

·         A peasant boy who is exclusive to the set

·         A male peasant who is exclusive to the set

·         A hunchback who is exclusive to the set and has a cane and a dark brown hood

·         The female merchant who is exclusive to this set and has the same  body and hair as the female Pirate but does have a double sided head (happy & scared), a slanted brick instead of legs

·         Two Royal knights, one of which carries a flagpole with blue and gold flags and the other who carries a small sword and has a double sided head (normal & scared) both of which are common within the Castle series

·         A Blacksmith who has a new exclusive body and has the same face as the governor in the Pirates series and wears a dark brown hood.

This is one of my personal favourite sets with very little cons which I don’t fell are worth talking about. This set does work well as a play set but it is more appropriate for an older audience and would make a great addition to any LEGO collection whether it be Castles, pirates or City. The set is well worth the money and if you can find it cheap then by all means take that chance and buy it even if you don’t like it.

 If you did want to turn it into a pirates set then might I suggest that you put barrels, crates and chests everywhere and place imperial solders and pirates inside and outside the buildings. Plus this would make a great set for someone who wants to make an Brick film animation.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Castle - Medieval Market Village
review:
The Medieval Market Village (10193) is a LEGO Castle set which came out in 2007. It comes with 8 minifigs and 1601 pieces. This set does include a few decals and there're no mistakes in the instructions and no missing pieces.

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/10193-1.jpg[/img]


Minifigures:

Knight 1: The first knight comes with a very basic blue uniform with gray pants, gray arms and a gray helmet. He has a double-printed face. On the one side he's happy and on the other one he's scared. The knight also comes with a spear.

Knight 2: The second knight comes with the same uniform as the other knight except the face is different. He has a basic LEGO City face and he has a nice flag.

Boy 1: The first boy comes with a chicken, a glass, a blond Harry Potter hair piece a smiley face and a double-printed torso which has a nice medieval look and he also got dark gray pants.

Boy 2: The second boy comes with the same torso as the other boy but his legs are smaller and don't move. He is smiling and has a long blond hair.

Old man: The old man comes with a brown hood, a stick, brown pants, brown arms, a dark gray belt and a brown backpack. On his face is a gray beard and he has the same torso as the two boys.

Blacksmith: The blacksmith comes with a brown hoos, yellow arms, black hands, black pants, a double-printed torso, a beard and a silver crystal which we've seen in the LEGO Power Miners and LEGO Rock Raiders theme a lot.

Woman 1: The first woman comes with a tan torso which has some cool markings on it, white arms, a brown dress, brown hair and a double-printed face. On the one side she's happy and on the other side she's scared.

Woman 2: The second woman comes with a black dress, a double-orinted torso, yellow arms, black hair, and a double-printed face. She also got a happy and a scared face. This minifig is also my favourite minifig in this set.

Medieval Market Village:

The medieval market village is one of my favourite sets I've owned and it's also a nice addition to your LEGO City. It comes with a treasure chest which has some gold in it, a weapons cache, 2 cows which appeared in this set for the first time, 3 birds, a rat, a white horse with a wagon which is full of hay, 3 buckets (one with flowers, one with apples and the other one has fish) and a sign. The market stand is also very nicely done and very sturdy. The tree is very detailed but the leaves are going to fall off very easily. I used to fix it with the extra studs which comes with this set. There're enough of them to fix it a little bit.

This set also has two buildings which can be opened. The tan building is the one for the blacksmith. The water mill does turn full 360° and if you turn it the hammer in the inside of this building moves up and down. There's also a nice fireplace in that building and a nice horse stable with two gates which opens and which have a bucket with a carrot. The windows on the next level do open and in the inside you can see a table, a chimney with a fire place, 2 pictures and a stool. The top of the table can be opened and you can hide some gold inside the table which is a nice play feature.

The last building is the pub which has a door which does open. In the outside you can see a big sign with a crown and there's also a stairway to the blue building. The pub has a nice table in the inside which has some chalices and you can slo see a beer barrel. On the second level you can see a very detailed bedroom with an awsome bed, a stool and a table with some make-up bottles.

All in all it's an awsome set and it was a real challenge to build the building. This set is a MUST HAVE and I'm sure that the LEGO Indiana Jones set 'Ambush in Cairo' might fit in this scene too.

Positive:

Great pieces which you can use for brickfilms or MOC's
Minifigs
Nice addition to your LEGO City
Comes with rare pieces
Gold coints
Lot's of play features


Negative:

Leaves of the tree fall off easily
It has a few stickers

All in all this set is a great model and I would highly recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full galery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de/

Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion
Review

author: finger2314
title: Great!
review: This set is my first proper set after being reintroduced into the world of lego- and what a whopper it is! It was really fun to build, although that's probably just lego in general, and the pieces are great! Some rare ones i think, and a nice colour scheme. I was astounded when i saw it on s@h for only £69.99, so i bought it quick, and if you're wondering to do the same, buy it! (only if it's under £80 though) My sister who's 9 has great fun with all the accessories and playing with the great figs- although her favourite parts are the birds, which every other review i read said were rubbish! Overall, a great set. The best I've had yet!

author: princeofgonville
title: The best set I have ever built
review:
Dear LEGO, please release more excellent sets like this!

My wife got me this set for Christmas. It is absolutely brilliant. It is fun and challenging to build, it is fun to play with. The parts and minifigs offer plenty of opportunity for play. The suggested age range is 12+ reflecting how complex this set is. I tipped each bag out into a separate container, and a lot of rummaging was still required. However, most of the construction uses standard bricks, which my inspire people to try creating additional buildings from the plans.

Gems include the working waterwheel-powered blacksmiths hammer, the furniture inside the inn, the market stand, and two cows. All the minifigs have character (some have two faces for added interest), and the tree is really special too.

It's really hard to find anything wrong with this set, apart from the fact that I would like to get a second one. I was mildly disappointed that the cobbled road shown on the box-front is not available. Overall a highly inspirational set with high buildability and playability.

author: jabbermabber
title: The best set ever
review:
The Medieval Market Village is without a doubt the best set ever and well worth £71.99. It has extremely well designed parts, the minifigures are good and the buildings are brilliant. 

Box/Instructions

The box is rather big and contains 18 bags (if you count the cow bag as two bags joined together. The box art shows the town in full swing while the back shows the buildings interior and the play features (the water-wheel hammer and the opening and closing buildings, though I don't know why a boy stealing some food and a knight being attacked by a cow is a play feature). The instruction books were not bent and the stickers are amazingly designed but there aren't that many which is good.

Parts

Some interesting parts to the set are the animals. The horse isn't newly designed or anything but it is my first horse. The two cows are wonderful with eye printing, and I don't know what everyone complains about the 'Made In China' on their sides, because I can not see it. The three birds (duck, chicken and rooster) are made brilliantly out of bricks using some rare bricks in good colours (flippers for feet and the red clip on brick on the chickens head). Comparing this chicken to the one in Mill Village Raid (which I hope to get soon) I prefer this one because it has more detail and colours while they are one colour with a little bit of printing. The tree is very interesting and mine doesn't seem to fall apart like everyone elses. The market stand also stands out to me as being amazing along with the hammer/water-wheel and oven in the blacksmiths, and the bed and staircase in the inn.

Minifigures

The best minifigure in my opinion is the bar maid in the dark green dress. Her hair is amazing and she is the only figure with lots of back-printing. The other figures with little back-printing are the two peasant boys, the peasant man and the blacksmith. There are three double-sided heads on the two females (happy and scared) and one of the knights (grin and scared).

The build

The build is quite complicated which makes it good. This is my first set without numbered bags which meant you could just empty the whole contents into one big pile and then find the ones you want.

The completed model

The model, when completed is rather impressive. What I feel it lacks is a base plate to put all the outside items on such as the tree and market stand.

Summary

The best set ever!

author: Ernst
title: The Perfect Village
review:
Overall 5 bricks : This is without doubt the best Lego set I built until now. The result is outstanding, esspecially the 2 buildings of course but also the other things like market stall and all other minifigures and accesoires. The only thing you can complain about is the stabilty of the tree that also looks great by the way. The only set you can compare it with is the Kingdoms Joust but if I have to choose the MMV wins by far.

 

Building 5 bricks : I'm not going to give a detailed review of the full built, that's done before and would be too long. I'll divide the built in 3 parts, the 2 buildings and the "loose parts". The first surprise is that the bags have no numbers, my advise is to first split all parts by color which makes the building more clear.

  • The "loose parts" : the things you have to built here are the market stall with great red/blue roof, the carriage with hay, the birds, weapon rack and of course the tree with blossom. Building is not too difficult only the tree is a bit unstable and tends to loose the green branches. Great civilian minifigures and 2 Knights from the Fantasy Era and 2 great looking cows.
  • The Black Smith Shop and Stable : great looking building with good Medieval colors and nice features. The waterwheel which is connected to the anvil and the stables on the right side. Great design with the bows on the groundfloor and the tan first floor where the Smith lives. In the interior of the first floor a small table and chair and a great fireplace. Good looking black roof with a chimney on the side of the building. The biggest surprise for me was how the black vehicle mudguard is used here as window ornament.

  • The tavern is in my opinion, thanks to the blue color, the nicest building of the two. The first floor with the brown, grey and black colors looks elegant thanks to the use of arched grey mudguards and the front door entrance. The bright blue color and use of pearl gold plates on the ground and first floor make this building a real eye catcher. The interior is great too with the wine or beer barrel, the small bar, the fireplace and of course the beautifull bed on the first floor. The tavern has also an entrance on the first floor with outside stairs.

 

Parts 5 bricks : I can be short here, all parts are great and usefull for all your other projects. The stickers in this set are kept to a minimum and very good. The stickered parts are single and can be used for possible Castle MOC's.

 

Playability 5 bricks : No further explanation needed I think, one look at the picture or finished set says it all. When finished I took a grey groundplate to put it on to be able to put the things steady in place. Later on I added another grey plate and added some sets like The Guarded Inn and The Prison Tower Rescue which fits in very well and had already a real small village.

 

Value 5 bricks : RRP in Holland is some €100,00 for this set but it is worth every single eurocent. I can advise anyone to buy as long as it is available new because I think this is a set that will rise in value same as the Modulars as soon as it is out of production. I was extremely lucky to find for half the price.

author: Javert24601
title: Outstanding (No other word for it)
review:
Well I will start this review off by saying that, if it hadn't been for my Dad finding the Cardiff LEGO store while there on holiday, I would never have this set! I walked in and this was next to all the kingdoms stuff. As we were staying in Wales for two weeks I had many chances to come to the LEGO store and even when my parents wanted to go to another store I said I would wait in the LEGO store. And that is what I did. I couldn't stop looking at this set, I probably spent over 3 hours altogether just marveling at the sight of such beauty! Then when it was time to go back to Chepstow again I remember looking at my mum with sad eyes! Which is quite ridiculous for a 16 year old boy! But I really did love it that much.

For weeks to come I would be thinking about this set and looking it up countless times on eBay and LEGO.com and then finally, almost 6 months later, I have the money to order it! So my Dad bought it off LEGO.com on the Saturday and it appeared on the Wednesday!

You should have experienced how I was feeling at the point of opening the parcel to find this inside it! It was like, I was a child again! (I have loved LEGO for many years)

Hastily I took a photo for Facebook (Which unfortunately didn't go down well with my friends, who hastily slagged me off for having such a thing!) and here is that very photo!

[img]https://fbcdn-sphotos-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/394144_104554746333919_100003381814728_23902_13860331_n.jpg[/img]


just looking back at this photo makes me want to relive the feeling of finally having it after months of waiting!

anyway without further ado I present my review!

After Opening:


The box contained 17 separate bags, 2 instruction booklets and a sheet of stickers.
The sizes of bags were mixed. Here is a photo I took after emptying the box:
[img]https://fbcdn-sphotos-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/408165_104554986333895_100003381814728_23904_2043052000_n.jpg[/img]

1601 Pieces:


[img]https://fbcdn-sphotos-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/394834_104558059666921_100003381814728_23929_393239297_n.jpg[/img]

After 2.5 gruelling hours of sorting bricks (made faster with Phantom of the Opera in the background) the dining table was mine! I thought before building it would be better if I sorted the bricks (as this is the biggest set I have ever had). Maybe you won't make this mistake (if you do make sure you have a good long musical album!)

I was surprised at some of the pieces in this set (for instance the parts usually used next to wheels on cars and also the grey car parts used as arches on the tavern and the Blacksmith's Crystal) and some pieces were lovely additions and completely new to me!

The Minifigures:


[img]https://fbcdn-sphotos-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/402948_104559503000110_100003381814728_23943_1706103513_n.jpg[/img]

In this set we get 8 minifigures, 2 Royal soldiers (tax collectors), a traveler, a teenage peasant, a child peasant, a stallholder and some other random woman peasant (probably the mother of the two boys) and a blacksmith peasant.

For someone who has bought this set without buying the previous castle sets, they get two knights with logos which are unrelated to recent sets which is a shame but I'll bet I'll be picking up the castle which has more of these knights (if I can find one for a reasonable price).

The peasants are lovely additions and have some great headpieces (the hoods especially). The torsos are all similar and despite the boys and the traveler having the same torso, they are all really nice! The two women have the same face but that's alright. I don't really mind though!

The Blacksmith has such an evil looking face to him but I really do like him!

The Build: 


Altogether it took me around 1.5 hours but for the inexperienced builder it will probably take considerably longer. It is a pretty straight forward build and because of the repetition in the tavern it may seem to take longer than it does but the results are outstanding so the build time is definately worth it!

First you make the minifigures as per normal in a lego set then comes the animals (1 horse, 2 cows and a chicken, a duck and a cockerel) and after this you build the cart with hay and the market stall and organize the tubs of fruit and the table with food. Then comes the tree followed by the 2 houses. All are simple builds and the market stall and tree do not take long to make at all!

Final Result:


[img]https://fbcdn-sphotos-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/401771_104561632999897_100003381814728_23967_1303586037_n.jpg[/img]

The final outcome of the set is beautiful! The Blacksmith shop part of the set features a water wheel that when turned makes the hammer, bang against the anvil. it also features a stable (complete with fodder, who'd have thought it?!) where you can store your horse (and feed a carrot to it) and cows (probably my fave figures of the set!). Upstairs features two portraits (stickers), a table with cup and stool to go with it and a safe!

The Tavern features a Bar, a barrel with tap, a bed, a dressing table (with hairbrush and what I believe is perfume), a dresser and a fireplace. The tavern also has a sticker for the sign (I guess the tavern is called "The King's Crown")and stairs leading to the upstairs part of the house.

How Does It Fit With The Old Castle Sets? :


Well I had already built the Guarded Inn (10000) and the Blacksmith Shop (3739) in the waiting period for the parcel and I thought since they were built I would take photos with them!

[img]https://fbcdn-sphotos-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/398617_104563616333032_100003381814728_23993_631041137_n.jpg[/img]

Now comparing this set to the older sets, it does fit in well but it also shows how far LEGO have come with their colours. In older sets the colours are nice and bright but are slightly lacking in eyecatchiness compared to the colours we have today! (yes I invented that word just for this review!)

OVERALL:

Overall this set is beautiful! I am so glad I finally got it after so long and I love everything about it. £71.99 for the biggest set I have had in terms of pieces? If you ask me that is AMAZING value! i am so glad LEGO have kept this set available to buy because people who don't have the money don't have to worry about waiting (Although LEGO told me on twitter we could see the end of this set in 2013 so I would bag it before it is gone!

I recommend this set to all LEGO builders EVERYWHERE. This is a set for everyone and anyone starting out with LEGO would also appreciate this as their introduction to the LEGO universe! I would say a kid of 7 years old would have trouble putting this together but someone from 10 years and older could probably crack the build (with a little help from bigger hands). If you love Castle themes and have no medieval buildings, definately get this set!

Thank You for reading and I hope you found this helpful! :)

author: ickleb
title: it comes with cows!!
review:
Fabulous set, good build and great addition to any castle.  wonderful and it comes with cows!

colours of the buildings are amazing, love the gold and the detail as always are fabulous.  perfect minifigures.

author: mathew
title: Lego won't make another...
review:
As a recent AFOL coming out of the dark ages I was overwhelmed by the number of Lego themes currently available.  I dipped my toes in starting with the Architecture theme, The Farnsworth House.  Really admired the detail compared to the sets from my childhood.  From there I bought a few City sets to build with my young son (soon to be three years old).  Bought a couple of Creator house sets.  Picked up a couple of discounted sets from the Atlantis and Prince of Persia themes.  I've MOC'd a couple of things with the accumulated bricks.  I was finally ready to go full in with a big set.  I am tempted by the modular buildings but spending $150 on a Lego set is still too much for me.  I kept coming back to the Medieval Market Village.  But man, $100 for Legos!  However, by this time I had already spent a couple of hundred on misc. sets.  When I started reading rumors about the MMV possibly being discontinued I decided to jump.  Alright, enough with the back story.

There really isn't much else to say about this set.  It's beautiful.  If I have a major complaint it's the lack of real organization of the pieces in the bags.  For example the included minifigs are pieced out in multiple bags.  To make the build more enjoyable you really need to pre-sort the pieces.  If you don't have the room or time to sort individual bricks (and believe me, at 1600 pcs. you'll need need a lot of room and time), best thing to do is buy inexpensive sandwich containers and break the bags open each into a separate container.  That's what I did.

I really like that both buildings are architecturally different.  Lego could of been lazy and just changed a few details between them.  The tan and black, blacksmith stable is the overall sturdier and larger building while the blue and gold, tavern inn is the more detailed and ornate.  The only thing I would like to add to the blacksmith stable would be a set of stairs (or even just a ladder) up to the second level.  I may try adding a stairway over the water mill section.  One minor quibble is that both buildings are hard to open and close using the small technic rod.  If you have small children who want to play with the set then I would advise removing the technic rods and just leave the buildings loose to open and close.

The tree is very nice looking when finished but you'll knock the leaves off if you move it around too much.  No big deal but limits some playability.  

The minifigs and other details really round out the set.  I even get a kick out of the horse poop.  Amazing how much poop can add to the playability of a set.  I would of liked a couple more minifigs like maybe a female child and another peasant adult male, but no real complaints.

Overall, if you are a recent AFOL, especially one who likes four walled buildings then you can't go wrong with Medieval Market Village.  I doubt Lego will make another village type set, at least one this detailed for a long time if ever again.  I also suspect that it will be discontinued this year (2012) so you should buy it before resellers start the gouging.

author: jeroenaa95
title: awesome set!
review:
This is my first review, so I don't really know how to make one. I am planning to review a lot more sets. I am just going to give you the pros and cons. After I had to wait a long time, I could finally buy one. I wanted this set a long time, but my parents didn't want me to buy it. Apparently, I am to old to play with LEGO's.

 

Pros:

- 8 minifigs: 2 soldiers, 1 blacksmith, 2 women, 2 young lads and 1 old traveller.

- 1601 pieces, that is much.

- lots of weapons: 1 axe, 3 spears, 2 knifes and 1 lance.

- 2 cool cows, a horse and a rat.

- awesome water mill.

- the tree.

- treasure chest with coins.

 

Cons:

there are none, except there should be more soldiers, but that is my opinion.

 

That was it fore this set. Be back soon with an other review.

author: naf
title: Great castle set, Lego shows the peasantry some love!
review:
I came out of my dark ages early in 2013, and I have to admit that while Lego has a lot more themes available then in my collecting hayday in the 80's, I wasn't very impressed with what they offered.   Although I didn't have many Castle sets as a kid, I liked the theme a lot.  I had the 6085 Black Monarch's Castle, 6066 Forestmen Camouflaged Hideout, and a few smaller sets.  I wanted more, but my family could only afford so much Lego and Space was my #1 theme.  The current Castle theme was the "fantasy era" which for some reason didn't impress me.  I love my fantasy, but in my mind Castle Lego is all about the knights, historically accurate looking castles (by Lego standards, anyway), and maybe a very few fantasy elements for flavor (like Black Monarch's Ghost).  The stuff I was seeing was a bit over the top.  Then I saw a review of the Medieval Market Village online and I knew I had to have it, it was unlike anything I've seen come out of Lego.  Unfortunately, the set was retired by this point, but I managed to find one online pretty close to retail so I grabbed it.  Enough with my personal history, let's get to the set.

Firstly, my favorite part of this set is the fact that it's all about the civilians!  Out of the 8 minifigures only 2 soldiers are included, and it looks like they're just in town collecting taxes and keeping the peace.  The rest of the figures are civilians.  There's an old beggar with a walking stick, a peasant woman with her two children selling vegetables, a blacksmith, and a tavern wench in a green dress (she's probably meant to the a working class tavern owner, but she's a wench in my town!)  You also get a bunch of animals.  Two brown cows, a horse (glad to see the design is the same after all these years), and brick built birds: a chicken, rooster, and duck.  These birds are cleverly designed and look great.

The two buildings are architecturally distinct.  The blacksmith shop has a plainer, more utilitarian look, while the tan and blue inn looks more ornate.  It has a working hammer that is connected to the water wheel on the outside of the building.  The stables are next to the shop, and has two stalls for horses.  The 2nd floor includes the living space for the blacksmith.  It has a neat looking wood-burning stove and some pictures hanging on the wall.  There's also a table on a barrel, with a gold coin hidden inside.  Hope the tax collectors outside don't find out!

The tavern has a bar with golden cups and a barrel of ale on the first floor, and a bedroom on the 2nd complete with a quilt over the bed, and a perfume bottle and hairbrush on the dresser.  This could be the tavern owner's personal quarters, or a room at the inn that travelers can rent.

The little extras fill out the scene nicely.  I've noticed that some larger Lego sets are simply a bunch of smaller builds that make up a scene.  Here, the two buildings are the star of the show, while the extras provide some extra details.  The little market stall has a nice colorful canopy that really brightens the set up.  You get baskets filled with apples, fish, and flowers for sale.  A small table is provided for feasting, and comes with a bowl of bread, some cheese, and a turkey.  The small horse cart is simple, but still very nice.  It comes with a few bales of hay to carry, but you can also transport full kegs of ale to the inn.  The last bit is a small weapons rack, with a few spears and a halberd.  I ended up putting this near my blacksmith shop as he's probably the one forging all of these weapons.

The build was very enjoyable, I took two evenings to finish it.  None of it feels repetitive, and the two buildings are different enough to feel distinct from each other.  The only problem I had was the 2nd floor of the blue inn/tavern building.  It was a little unstable until I got the 2nd floor and roof attached.  I ended up sorting the bricks into 3 bins, one for the very tiny pieces, one for small-medium pieces, and a 3rd for the larger pieces.  This seemed to work well enough, I don't see how further sorting would have made the build go any faster.  I never had a problem finding pieces.

If I had to criticize the set, it would be for the fact that I wish they wouldn't have put tiles on all the flat surfaces.  I know they look nicer, but without studs, items such as food and perfume bottles tend to fall off if jostled slightly.  I might replace these surfaces with studded plates so that the food doesn't go flying whenever someone touches the buildings.  Also, I think a few more minifigures and another market stall would have added more to the outdoor market aspect to this set.

Overall, this is a great set and I wouldn't hesitate to pick this up.  I think kids and AFOL's alike will enjoy this.  There is lots of playability here on it's own for the kids, even more so when you add other castle sets to it.  However, the playability is limited to posing, crafting items with your little blacksmith, selling goods, and running an inn.  If you're looking for a battle, it's not here.  It makes a nice display piece for the adults.  I added the Lego Kingdoms Mill Village Raid set to expand the village; these sets go great together.  Although Medieval Market Village is a Castle set (from the fantasy era), I feel like the Kingdoms sets go better with it since they don't have the fantasy elements that Castle includes.  Medieval Market Village also fits in nicely with older Castle sets.  Black Monarch's Castle overlooks the village, while my forestmen attack the tax collectors bothering the peasants.

Medieval Market Village - buy it!  You won't regret it!

author: mediAFOL
title: Simply magnificent
review:
Becoming an AFOL, I knew nothing of post-Classic castle sets. My Seventies yellow Castle was bought and built, but I wanted more. I then discovered the greatest Lego set ever released.

It was pricey to get hold of once retired, but it was worth every penny. Again, hinged buildings hark back to the yellow castle, but here the result is much, much better. Closed, we have the much-desired complete building (no open backs here). Open, we have a considerable length of medieval street-front.

Everything about this set shines, but the focus should rightly remain on the two buildings. There is delightful contrast between the grey and earth tones of the industrial mill and the gorgeous dusty blue of the posher tavern. The windows in both buildings are simply beautiful, and the differences again add to the interest of the whole scene - the roofs run in different directions, and the eternal staircase of the tavern bridges the external to the internal.

As for the interiors... This was my first experience of what have become very common furniture builds, and I am still knocked out by them. The patchwork quilt and sideboard are delightful, as is the anvil. They bring joy through their economy of pieces, and through lack of specialist piece use. I love them.

Together with the Mill Village Raid, this creates the perfect town and country combination for your medieval Lego world. I can't stress enough how fabulous the Medieval Market Village is.
